body: Personally, I think the biggest gains could be made if the fitted estimators could be cached somehow, using a mechanism like `lru_cache` on fitted objects.

here is an earlier attempt
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2024

but I do not understand why this did not lead to the expected gains. Sth might not work with the caching scope?
Btw, who is paying for all this computational time on GitHub?.. It's not just about developer experience, is it?

> Btw, who is paying for all this computational time on GitHub?.. It's not just about developer experience, is it?

Afaik we have a free version, it says "[GitHub Actions usage is free for both public repositorie](https://docs.github.com/en/billing/managing-billing-for-github-actions/about-billing-for-github-actions#about-billing-for-github-actions)s" , but we might actually want to have more runners in the future if there is money around :)
https://docs.github.com/en/actions/learn-github-actions/usage-limits-billing-and-administration#usage-limits

so, I just notice that in the #2024 attempt, the `lru_cache`-d function is inside a class, which won't work properly.

That might be it?

I.e., the solution would be:

* take #2024 and adapt it into the current test framework, resolving perhaps a million merge conflicts
* take the cached function `_cached_estimator_fitting`, and move it *outside* any of the classes

... done?

rename.from: Cut down test time to under 10 min
rename.to: [MNT] Cut down test time to under 10 min

body:
I this this is really great. Some ideas to throw out there:

- what would people's thoughts be on just running CI/CD tests on files changed until a particular PR is ready to merge, and then on the merge action we trigger the full CI/CD run? Might help with increasing iteration speed (seems like most bugs come up on files directly related to the PR) but ensures that a full QC check is done before the branch is merged. 
- also with regards to caching and how to store/access the file - it is actually possible to do this via [Github Actions directly](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/caching-dependencies-to-speed-up-workflows).  Not sure if that helps with this particular discussion, but seems like it might.

>what would people's thoughts be on just running CI/CD tests on files changed until a particular PR is ready to merge, and then on the merge action we trigger the full CI/CD run?

That's a brilliant idea, and basically what `pytest-testmon` does, this avenue was explored in issue https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2530.

I think we got stuck at the question "but how would you know which tests are those that touch the changed files/lines"? There is also a problem with `testmon` that it does not detect files that the `all_estimator` crawler does, say, if an entire estimator is added.

I have to apologize to @tarpas who put work into this, we got stuck and I was thinking about how to ensure that really all classes get tested, for weeks, until the point I eventually forgot by accident that the discussion was still ongoing, sorry @tarpas!
(should have tracked that on one of the boards)

So, @miraep8, do you have a good idea how you would technically implement, given `sktime`'s current test set-up, to test only files changed in a PR?

> also with regards to caching and how to store/access the file - it is actually possible to do this via [Github Actions directly](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/caching-dependencies-to-speed-up-workflows). Not sure if that helps with this particular discussion, but seems like it might.

I also overlooked @tarpas last post which seems to suggest something similar. I.e., first test with the "imperfect" `testmon`, and then gradually add in tests.

The problem though would be that it would miss new files and estimators therein, if I am not mistaken.

But, we could supplement the idea by running `check_estimator` on all classes in new files, then it might cover enough to be practicable?

I think running `check_estimator` on all classes in new files would get us most of the way there.  It might not be ideal for cases where we are modifying `BaseObject` or something like that though.  Thoughts on this suggestion to help us catch all potentially affected files: 

- Lets create an object which is a dict() (lets call it `importsMe`)
- The keys to this object are module names within `sktime`
- The values are a list all the other modules within `sktime` that import a particular module named by the key
- This is something that can easily be created once by crawling through all modules in `sktime` and using `modulefinder`, or `inspect` or something like that to get a list of modules imported.
- I believe the best way to do it might be to list indirect imports as well, eg if `C` imports from `B` which imports from `A`, but `C` does not directly import from `A`, we would still want `C` to show us as a value for key `A`

So my understanding from the current CI/CD is that we currently only run the style checks on files which have been modified.  (I only know this because I thought the current CI/CD is great and copied a lot of the code for it for my own repo!).  But that means we have access to a list of modified modules.  We can now do the following:

- use the changed files to update `importsMe` (ie if any of our modules are new or import from something new we add it to the list of modules importing that particular module).
- lastly we run tests on the changed module, and on all modules which inherit from it. 

Drawback - my current implementation might not handle well if an import gets dropped, but that is something that could be added it if is important. 

Thoughts?

Summary: I think this is an excellent idea!

We may have to modify it though for functionality that itself uses `import_module`, possibly with dynamic imports.
I think this is isolated to `all_estimators` though, so we may need to think around that.

>Thoughts on this suggestion to help us catch all potentially affected files:

Ok, your `dict` is the transitive closure of the directed acyclic graph of module imports, where directed edges are encoded as (key, value) pairs.

>Drawback - my current implementation might not handle well if an import gets dropped, but that is something that could be added it if is important.

I think that's easy to solve, you build the transitive import graph for the changed and the unchanged version (pre and post PR), and also test everything where an outgoing edge changes.

@tarpas might be able to comment on whether `pytest-testmon` is already doing this or a similar thing.

>I only know this because I thought the current CI/CD is great and copied a lot of the code for it for my own repo!

Where is that? Is that a secret project?

issue.title: [ENH] caching fitted estimators in base estimator testing - lru_cache

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Splices https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2024 into the current test framework and `sktime` version, in an attempt to address https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2890

Attempt using `lru_cache`, compare #2913 which uses indirect fixtures.

labels.name: maintenance

issue.body:
Splices https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2024 into the current test framework and `sktime` version, in an attempt to address https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2890

Attempt using indirect fixtures, compare #2913 which uses `lru_cache`.

body:
Hi. I prioritized other things because testmon doesn't support pytest --pyargs and also because I'm not able to run the test suite on my M1 Macbook (tensorflow started crashing under rosetta 2 and there are still problems to install it natively)

What @miraep8 describes sounds like static analysis. testmon doesn't do that, it uses only runtime coverage data. That's why it might have problems to pick up constants initialized on module import.

Would you be willing to go away from using --pyargs? That's the show stopper in #2530
As for catching all estimators/classes I assume it would be easy to make the collection a function as opposed to a module constant and that would be the easiest way to allow testmon to catch changes there.

> it would be easy to make the collection a function

It already is a function! We are using `all_estimator` internally from the registry module.

>Would you be willing to go away from using --pyargs?

Hm, @lmmentel, could you kindly reply to this? I pinged you in the #2530 issue and you did not react, maybe you did not see it?

Now, since you opened this issue, you may like to comment?
